sp.p: No, I did not know at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But no man in England but would have asked ſuch a Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: No he ſaid, they were four Strangers: But, ſaid I, did you bring them out of Italy? Nor, ſaith he, they are four Iriſh Gentlemen that I brought over with me, worthy Perſons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: And what Religion was he of that ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: He was a Catholick, one that bought all into a Colledge, that did ſo here before he went.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: He belonged to the Benedictine Monks, my Lord, in the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And what was he that he ſpoke to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: He was a Catholick too, he was Servant to one that belongs to the Queens Chappel.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Did you underſtand what the Buſineſs was they ſaid they were to do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: Not till I read Mr Coleman's Tryal, and then I did gueſs theſe were the perſons that were to have killed the King at Windſor.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſaw them not, did you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: No, they were in charge of this Anthony, that is now in ſome place in the Queens Chappel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Atkins.
sp.p: Did he ſpeak to Anthony to have a care of them, or to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: To Anthony, he was the perſon that was to take care of them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is Anthony a Papiſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: Yes, a very ſtrong Papiſt, and we uſed to be often together; but now he is jealous, and will not come near me to talk with me as we uſed to do.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now I underſtand the reaſon of it, why he did not ask the Queſtion; it was not likely he ſhould, for it was not ſpoken to him, but he ſtood by all the while the diſcourſe was to Anthony, another man, and it was to him that he ſpoke to have a care of the four Iriſh men, for they would do their Buſineſs. What did Anthony ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: He promiſed he would have as much care of them, as of his own life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is this Anthony to be found?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: My Lord, Anthony is a Portugueſe, and the Queens Confeſſors man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: He was ſeen this morning; they call him Signior Antonio.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: You ſhould have an Order to take this ſame Anthony into Cuſtody, but in order to the finding of him, let him go to my Lord Oſſory.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr Tiſſer, we give you an Order for the taking of this Signior Antonio, you will find him at Somerſethouſe; for the doing of this, we do adviſe you to wait upon my Lord Oſſory, and tell him that you have ſuch an Order, but that out of Reverence to the Queen, we have alſo ordered you to wait upon him, to deſire him to ſend him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: What is become of this Hankinſon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Buſs.
sp.p: He is abroad beyond the Seas, my Lord, for he ſaid he was come thither to take leave of his Friends, and was to go the next morning into Surrey, and ſo away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what have you now to ſay Mr Langhorne?

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: I conceive this laſt Witneſs ſays nothing to me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p:
He ſpeaks only to the Plot in general, as the firſt Witneſſes did; but that which is upon you, is as to Mr Oats, who ſpeaks to every Article of the Indictment expreſly; and Mr Bedloe ſays, he did not only ſee you Tranſcribe and Copy out that Treaſonable Letter, but he carried
other Letters to you, which you promiſed to Tranſcribe; and theſe are Overt-acts that make you a Party to the Treaſon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Beſides your diſcourſe with Coleman, after the Letters were Tranſcribed.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Theſe two Gentlemen were Parties in this ſuppoſed Crime, the two Witneſſes which do concern me, are Mr Oats, and Mr Bedloe, and they both of them clearly appear to have been in the ſame Treaſon that I ſuppoſe they charge me with; I deſire to know whether they have had their Pardon or no?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I believe they have. Mr Oats, and Mr Bedloe, Have you your Pardons?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I have three.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have two Pardons under the Broad Seal, but I don't know what is in them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: But make your Objection how you will, whether they had, or whether they had not, they are Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I never gave any Evidence till I had my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Langhorne.
sp.p: I ask for this reaſon, I look upon your Lordſhip and the Court as my Counſel, to adviſe me in matters of Law, whether theſe be good Witneſſes or not?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We do tell you, that if we had not judged them to be Witneſſes, we would not have heard them.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: They come under the ſame reaſon of Law with an Approver, having had their Pardon; I don't ſay they are directly Approvers, but I conceive they come under the ſame reaſon of Law with them, and then if the Approver be pardoned, by the Law the Appellee ought to be diſcharged; and methinks by the ſame reaſon, theſe men having been participes Criminis, and having got their Pardons, ought not to be ſuch ſubſtantial Witneſſes againſt the Priſoner at the Bar. But, my Lord, I have one thing yet further to ask, I deſire to know whether they have not received any Rewards, or Gratifications, for the Diſcovery they have made, and the Service they have done? And whether they do not expect further Rewards?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is there any Allowance to be made to you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: I have received a Reward, by disburſing 6 or 700 l.out of my Pocket, and I don't know when I ſhall ſee it again.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: Mr. Langhorne does ſuppoſe that the Witneſſes are corrupted and bribed; Do you think Mr Langhorne, that the King will bribe his Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Langhorne
sp.p: My Lord, I only propoſe it as a Queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Would you anſwer that Queſtion your ſelf?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: If you can ſuppoſe there was any Subornation or Corruption, call your Witneſſes, and prove it; but for their receiving ſuſtenance and maintenance from the King, that is but reaſonable, and can be no Objection. And you your ſelf know, that an Approver, while he is in that ſervice, hath a Peny a day, which in ancient Times was a great matter for livelihood and ſuſtenance; ſo that any Reward that they have, if you can prove it by Contract or Subornation, you cannot make an Objection.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: My Lord, I am informed by a Priſoner in the Gao • , that Mr Bedloe hath received 500 l.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you can prove any thing do, prove what you can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: That 500 l. was about a particular Fact.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But pray what is his Name?

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: His Name is Mr Reading.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: He is an infamous perſon, he hath ſtood in the Pillory, we can't take him for a Witneſs; but now I'll tell you for the 500 l. 'tis a thing we all know of. It was a Reward for a particular buſineſs, not relating to the Plot, but it was for the diſcovery of the Murtherers of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: I think Mr Prance is here, that will give an account of that, for Bedloe diſcovered him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I am ſo far from having any benefit by this diſcovery, that I am 700 l. out of Pocket.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Ellys.
sp.p: You ſhall have the liberty to make what good defence you can for your ſelf, and prove what you can, you muſt not go this way to work.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty reaſonable for us to give a publick ſatisfaction to all the World, that we do nothing under-hand, but that we do in this Caſe as in all other Caſes; any thing that is fit to be anſwered, they ſhall anſwer, and perchance in this Caſe ſomething more than can be ſtrictly required of us. 'Tis notorious enough, that Mr Oates and Mr Dedloe have been fed at the King's charge, and it cannot be objected againſt them, and need not be wink'd at, for they were Parties in the Plot. And when they come to make the Diſcovery, without which we ſhould never have known the Plot, for you know 'tis hard to diſcover any Crime, Forgery, or the like, but by one that hath been privy to it, and a guilty perſon; yet theſe men always have been, and are in Law Witneſſes, and 'tis juſt they ſhould have a Competency to maintain them, ſince they came for the Publick Good to make ſuch Diſcoveries.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: And that particular Sum of Mony was paid to Mr Bedloe, in purſuance of the King's Proclamation, which we all know, which was all publickly done.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: The Reaſon why I preſs this was, becauſe of the Proclamation, which was to invite Perſons to come, touching the diſcovery of this Plot; and to encourage them to it by a promiſe or reward. I think it may be reaſonable enough, where any perſon that is charged with a Crime doth abſent, to propoſe a Reward for the bringing him in. But I think it is hard, that when a Priſoner is in Cuſtody, Witneſſes ſhould be brought in againſt him by ſuch means.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: You do Artificially go off from the Point, Anſwer the Evidence that hath been given againſt you, and you ſhall be heard; but you labor very much, and trouble your ſelf to make Anſwer to another matter that is not pertinent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does your Defence conſiſt wholly of this ſort of matter, objecting the incompetency of the Witneſſes? Can you make no Anſwer to the Fact?

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p:
I muſt tell your Lordſhip, My whole Defence muſt run to diſable the Witneſſes, for my Lord I was committed to Newgate the 17th of October, and I have been kept there a cloſe Priſoner till this day was ſeven-night, or Friday the laſt Week, I never converſed with any Friend, or any Relation, nor knew any thing of News, but only with ſome few
perſons ſent by Authority of the Houſe of Commons or the Council. And I was never examined by any ſince I was committed. I never heard what was charged againſt me, and I could not foreſee what theſe men could teſtifie, becauſe I was not confident whereupon they would proceed; therefore I can have no Defence, unleſs it be by leſſening their Credit, 'tis impoſſible I ſhould.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do, leſſen it if you can. If you have any Witneſſes to take off their Credit, or contradict them, call them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: But I would ſay one thing to you Mr. Langhorne; you ſeem to put a very ill Conſtruction upon the Kings Proclamation, as if it were to invite and encourage perſons to come and ſwear about a Plot, where there was none; it was to invite people to make a further Diſcovery of a Plot that lay Cloſe, and we could not fully Diſcover for the preſervation of the King and Kingdom without ſuch a means.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: He did propoſe a Reward.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Atkins.
sp.p: Ay in order to a further Diſcovery of that Plot which we had Evidence of before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: And ſo you would be cloſe in all your Accounts, and none ſhould be rewarded that could make us any diſcovery of them, but preſently their Teſtimony muſt be gone. 'Tis very fine, but the Court over-rules it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Langhorne, whatſoever you object of this kind does fly in the face, and reflect upon the integrity and wiſdom of King, Lords and Commons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: For it was done by the advice of all Three.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you'l go on and prove any thing, but pray don't ſpend our time to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Call Parry and Townely, and Doddington, and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, here are Papiſts come into the Court with their Swords on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: They will not draw them here.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor.
sp.p: 'Tis well enough, 'tis well enough Dr. Oates, you are ſafe enough here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who will you have firſt?

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: I would have Hilſly ſet up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J▪
sp.p: What would you ask him?

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip hath heard Dr. Oates affirm he came over ſuch a time in the Pacquet Boat with Mr. Hilſly. I deſire to know whether that be true or no?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I can help you in that, for we had him and his Companions here yeſterday, but however we will hear them again, if you will have them. Do you know Mr. Oats?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: I do my Lord very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you come over from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: I came over the 24th of April, N. S.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Mr. Oats come with you?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: No, he did not.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he did leave me there, but I overtook him at Calis.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you there now, you did leave him there, but he over-took you at Calis. Did you leave him there?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: I did leave him there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but he over took you then, did he not?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: No, he did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He anſwers as he did yeſterday, that he did not come over with him; you loſt your mony did you not?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did you looſe it? Did you looſe it at play?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter how I loſt it, I did not looſe it at play.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I'll tell the Court if your Lordſhip pleaſe how he loſt it, he lent a great deal of mony to a Gentleman, who went away with his mony and left him to pay the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you to that?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: That is very true, and I confeſs it, but what is all this? nothing to the matter, he was told this by ſome body elſe, I never ſaw him, nor ever any man in the Ship ſaw him come over with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I'll tell you what then; firſt here is ſomething now that you would not confeſs yeſterday, nor indeed would you confeſs it now, I asked you how you loſt your mony; you ſee Mr. Oats can tell you how it was, tho' you wont tell us, ſo that tho' this be a ſecret, he knows it, and how could he know this ſecret unleſs he were there?

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: There is one that I met by the way that did tell him this Story.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Oats?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What diſcourſe had you with him concerning Hilſly?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: Why he told us of his departure.

sp.speaker: L. J. C.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: After he was gone away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long after?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: Three our four days.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſaid he to you?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: He only told us he was gone.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What elſe ſaid you of him?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: He only ſaid he departed out of the Colledge then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did you ſay to Mr. Oats about it?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: I don't remember what I ſaid in particular?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hilſly, call up the other perſon that you ſay told Mr. Oats.

sp.speaker: Hilſly.
sp.p: He is not here my Lord, but here is one that was in the Company when he told it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was by?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: Mr. Burnaby, who came thither the firſt of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hearken to me, when you talked with Mr. Oats concerning Mr. Hilſly's being gone from the Colledge, was there any body by?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was Mr. Burnaby by when Mr. Oats and you talked about Mr. Hilſly?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, there was Mr. Oats with me, and Mr. Burnaby put himſelf into our Company in the Garden, and he acquainted me with this Story.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: He ſaid he met this Gentleman, and that this Gentleman was cheated of his money.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did he tell you he was cheated?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: I dont't know the occaſion, but he ſaid a fellow cheated him of the mony.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was that all he ſaid?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, but I do not remember upon what occaſion, he ſaid he was cheated by a ſhirking fellow.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he name the place he met him at?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: I don't know my Lord whether he mentioned it or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So that Mr. Oats names the place which he was never told; and unleſs he was there, how could he then tell it?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: But this does not prove that I ſpeak againſt my Conſcience, that does not argue.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, the anſwer is this Mr. Langhorne. You would charge Mr. Oats with falſity in ſaying he came over in the Pacquet-Boat with Hilſly, and you call up him, and he ſays, he did not come, but he left him at St. Omers; Mr. Oats comes and ſays, 'tis true, he left me there, but I over-took him at Calis, by this very token, ſaid he, you were cheated of your mony by a perſon that you lent it to, who went away, and left you to pay the Reckoning. When I asked Mr. Hilſly how he could tell if it were true that he was not with him, he anſwered, he was told it by another; but when I come to know what that other perſon ſaid, it was no more than this, he ſaid in Mr. Oats's hearing Mr. Hilſly was cozened of his mony, but did not ſay how, nor by whom, nor where.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Now to prove that what Mr. Hilſly ſaid is true, and that therefore Mr. Oats his knowledge muſt come by another hand, I deſire that the Witneſs may be asked how long Mr. Oats was at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long was Mr. Oats at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: From December till June he was there, except one particular day that he went to Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you ſaw him almoſt every day.

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You have 15 or 16 Witneſſes that will ſay all this; but yet if you will we will call them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When went he away, do you know that?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: He went in June, I cann't certainly ſay the day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, call another.

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let me ſpeak, if your Lordſhip pleaſe to let me give you my Reaſon, why I might ſee him; I ſaw him in the Refectory; he had a little Table by himſelf diſtinct from the reſt, and dining together in a publick place, it was impoſſible but we ſhould ſee his place empty, if he were gone, and I know the number of my own School, and can tell whether any one be abſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What becauſe he ſat at a Table by himſelf therefore you think he was there all the while.

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: Certainly if I may believe mine own eyes, I ſaw him there every day.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Baron.
sp.p: Were you there every day your ſelf?

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was, I did not miſs one day I had no Infirmity.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr Oats hath affirmed that there was with him when he came over in April, Sir Robert Brett.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays only he believes ſo, he ſays poſitively he came over in the company of Sir John Warner, Sir Thomas Preston, and he thinks alſo Sir Robert Brett, but is not poſitive.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: This he affirmed both in his Narrative, and upon Oath in the Lords Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Shew any thing that he was ſworn to here.

sp.speaker: M. Just. Atkins.
sp.p: But what ſays this Lad more, let him ſpeak, for he is very full of it.

sp.speaker: 3d Witneſs.
sp.p: The firſt Day of May I ſaw him in the Garden with a Lay-Brother at Kittle-pins in the view of all the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Let us examine him as to perſons, and then refer it to the Lords Regiſter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why if you will prove ſomething Mr. Oats hath ſworn there, that you can contradict, firſt prove what he ſwore, and then contradict it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Pray take notice you muſt not go to oppoſe him in any thing of that Oath, unleſs he hath ſworn it here; whatſoever there be there, except he hath ſworn the ſame here, 'tis in vain to object it, for he cannot be intended to have Witneſs to make good what he ſwore there.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: Let us hear what he does offer.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Under favour Mr. Oats hath acknowledged what he ſwore there was true.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You are miſtaken Mr. Langhorne, indeed when you asked him that Queſtion, he ſaid as far as what concerned what he ſwore here, was true, and he is bound at this time to anſwer no more.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Then as to Sir John Warner, I deſire my Witneſſes may be examined.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe they may be here, and ſay the ſame they did yeſterday; that he did not ſtir from his houſe at Watton all April and May.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he lived there all that while.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What year?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: In year 1678.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is the time that Oats ſays he came over with him. You ſaw him almoſt every day did not you?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I did, only four days that I was abſent, being ſent by him to St. Omers at a great Feaſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And when you came back you found him there?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You are his Gardner, are you not?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſtay all thoſe four days at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: I was ſent to the high Kirk, and carried ſome Inſtruments for the Muſick, and there I ſtayed four days, and the laſt day of April, and the firſt, and ſecond, and third of May. And I ſaw Mr. Oats there in the houſe, and I ſaw him going into the Refectory to dinner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays that Sir John Warner was at home all April and May, that he himſelf was abſent but four days, that he left him there, and when he came back, found him there, and that in the four days he was at St. Omers, he ſaw Mr. Oats, which was the laſt of April▪ the firſt, ſecond and third of May. You don't know when Mr. Oats went away?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: No, my Lord, not I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Was Sir John Warner there all June?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: My Lord, I can't tell that, I only ſpeak to April and May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Thoſe are the two Months that fit him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Why how come you not to remember that, as well as the other two, for that is ſince?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Becauſe I took not ſo much notice of him in thoſe Times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to take more ſpecial notice of them two Months, than of the other?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Becauſe our Rector did then come into England, and he took the charge of the Houſe upon him in the Rector's abſence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did he come?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: He came the 24th of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Pray who is your Rector? What is his Name?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Sir Francis Williams.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was Sir John Warner in June and July?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: And where was he in August and September?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: He went out of Town, but where, I am not certain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You were Gardener there then.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why can't you as well tell me then where he was in June and July, as in April and May? Anſwer me plainly.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: I think he was there all that time, but I can't be certain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why not ſo certain for thoſe two Months, as you are for the other?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Becauſe I did not take ſo much notice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How come you to take more notice of the one, than the other? That he was there in April and May, rather than that he was there in July.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Becauſe the Queſtion, my Lord, that I came for, did not fall upon that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now he hath anſwered plainly; when I asked the Queſtion, Why he did not take ſo much notice of thoſe Months, as he did of April and May? He anſwered me, Becauſe the Queſtion did not fall upon thoſe Months; and that, without all Queſtion, is a plain and an honeſt Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Indeed he hath forgot his Leſſon, you ſhould have given him better Inſtructions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Look you Mr Langhorne, If he be to be believed, and that he doth not ſpeak falſly, or more than he knows, it is impoſſible that Oats's Teſtimony and his can ſtand together; for he directly affirms he ſaw Mr Oats the laſt of April, the 1ſt, 2d, and 3d of May. Now Mr Oats ſays he was here then; ſo that theſe two cannot ſtand together. The Queſtion then is, Whether he be to be believed? And whether he does not come wilfully, or prepared? the Jury have beard what a kind of teſtimony he gives, when the Queſtion was asked him, How he came to take notice of the Months of April and May, more than of June and July? And why he was more ſure Sir John Warner was there at the one time, than at the other? Why,
ſaid he, becauſe the Queſtion falls upon thoſe former Months, and not upon thoſe of June or July. Now that does ſhake all that was ſaid before, and looks as if he came on purpoſe, and prepared for thoſe Months, and now this, I am afraid, will go through all your St Omers men.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Indeed I doubt it will go a great way, to ſhake all their Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: You Gardener, what do you ſay was your Rector's name?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: Sir Francis Williams.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: And he came over in April or May, Did he?

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: He came over the 24th of April.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: Why that is the time that Mr Oats came over, and he was one of the perſons that he ſaid came over with him.

sp.speaker: 4th Witneſs.
sp.p: No, he came alone only with a certain Officer of the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Pray let Gifford be asked the ſame Queſtion about Sir John Warner; for if he did come, as he ſaith, from Watton to St Omers, at that time he muſt ſee him at St Omers, for he was at St Omers then. The Queſtion is about Sir John Warner, if he were at Watton, or St Omers, then he could not come over with Mr Oats.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Sir John Warner?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: I ſaw him about June, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: I ſaw him there in St Omers Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: In June or July, when he invited me over to Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This man does not ſerve the turn, he does not know the Month upon which the Queſtion runs.

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: The firſt day of May there was a great Feaſt, St Fortunatus and Gordianus, and then I ſaw Mr Oats four days, and he was there all the Month of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was Sir John Warner then?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: I cannot tell, but at St Omers I ſaw Mr Poole, and Sir Robert Brett at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Mr Poole come over with you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Witneſs, when did Mr Poole come from St Omers?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: He came firſt to St Omers with Mr Whitebread, he was my Maſter of Muſick, and he taught me, and it was impoſſible he ſhould be miſſing without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But he was gone to England long before that; and he could not be at England and St Omers, at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: You ſay right, he could not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came he from St Omers?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: In the Month of June or May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Or April.

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: No, it was the Month of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Theſe are but Collateral Matters, Mr Langhorne, for you to ſtand upon this, it ſpends time to no purpoſe; but the great Queſtion is, Friend, whether you don't miſtake the Month?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, yes, (at which the people laugh'd) no, no, I don't miſtake the Month, I only ſpeak the Truth according to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can you ſo preciſely remember the Month of May he was there; for when I asked you when he went away, you could hardly tell the Month.

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, Mr Oats ſays, in the Month of May he was in England, but I ſay I ſaw Mr Poole then at St Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But the great Queſtion is, Whether you are to be believed? We know you anſwer the Queſtion poſitively, but my reaſon why I fear you are not to be believed, is, becauſe you are ſo preciſe, that Mr Poole taught you all May, but I ask you once more, Was it in June, or was it in May?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: It was about June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: May is about June. Why then you cannot tell. Was it in June?

sp.speaker: 5th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it was; it was about June. And this is nothing but what I know, for I actually ſaw Mr Oats there at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I'll tell you what Mr Langhorne, uſe your diſcretion, call whom you will, and we will hear them as long as you will; but we had Sixteen of them yeſterday, that did all ſpeak to the ſame purpoſe, but in anſwer to theſe Sixteen Witneſſes, Mr Oats did produce, and he will produce again ſix or ſeven Witneſſes, and one of them a Papiſt, if not a Prieſt, who do ſwear that Mr Oats was here in April and May; I'll tell you beforehand, do you as you will.

div.stage: Then one Baille ſtood up, and being a Foreigner, an Interpreter was called.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did you ſee Sir John Warner in April and May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he ſaw him actually at St Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What all the Month of May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: Yes, he ſays he converſed with him all the Month of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And was he there all April, and converſed with him then?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: Yes, he ſays every day of both Months. He ſays he ſaw him from the firſt Sunday in April, to the 14th of May, and converſed with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did Sir John Warner go the 14th of May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: My Lord, he ſays he went for one day only to St Omers, and came back again.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him, How he knows this?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he was employ'd about a Building by Sir John Warner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr Oats, and where?

sp.speaker: Carpenteir.
sp.p: I ſpeak as to Sir Thomas Preſton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you as to Sir Thomas Preſton?

sp.speaker: Carpenter.
sp.p: I ſaw him at Liege.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Carpenter.
sp.p: All the Months of March, April, May, and June, he was ſtill there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When went he away?

sp.speaker: Carpenter.
sp.p: In the time of the Vacancies.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When is that?

sp.speaker: Carpenter.
sp.p: That is from the beginning of August, till the end of September.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came he again?

sp.speaker: Carpenter.
sp.p: When they came to School again, and that was in the 2d or 3d of October.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Were you with him all that time?

sp.speaker: Carpenter.
sp.p: Yes, I was. He hath not been in England theſe three Years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you been there?

sp.speaker: Carpenter.
sp.p: I have been four Years, and I never knew that he was abſent, but in the time of the Vacancies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Call another Witneſs.

div.stage: Then ſtood up another Witneſs, who being a Dutch man, and not ſpeaking Engliſh, an Interpreter was called for him alſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what comes he for?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he comes to teſtifie, That Sir John Warner was at Watton in April; and he ſays he ſaw him there, from the 14th of April, to the 25th of April.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And then to what time?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he was there till the 16th of May.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Ask him where he was the beginning of April?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he was Superior there in the Houſe, and did Govern.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him where he was in the latter end of May?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he was likewiſe in the Houſe, ſave only one day, when he went to St Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then he might have ſaid, in ſhort, he was there all April and May.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: Call John Joſeph.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: What do you ask him, Mr Langhorne?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: That which I ſay is this, That Sir Thomas Preſton was at Liege in March, April, May, and June, in the Year 1678.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee him every day in thoſe Months?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: That I cannot well tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee him every other day?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I believe I did once in two or three days.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he in July?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: He was at Liege too. He was obliged to be ſo; but in the time of the Vacancies in August, he was abſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you ſay he was all thoſe Months, March, April, May, June and July there.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, thoſe four Months I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What became of him in August, when he went, during the Vacancies, abroad? Do you know whither he went?

sp.speaker: Sir Creſ. Levins.
sp.p: Do you know whether he went into England.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I never heard that he was in England.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did he return again?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: When they began School, and that is in the beginning of October.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs.
sp.p: I can ſay that Mr. Oats never ſtirred out of the Colledge at that time when he ſays he came to England, that is, he ſays he came upon Monday the 25th of April, but he did not, for that day he went into the Infirmary, and he ſtayed at St. Omers all April and May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And how much longer?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs.
sp.p: A great part of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there the 20th of June?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs.
sp.p: I am ſure he was, but how much longer I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he in February and March?

sp.speaker: 10th Witneſs.
sp.p: He was there too; in January he lay out one night, and that was at Watton, but I am ſure he did not come over the 24th of April, N S. as he ſays.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Now he ſays, it is New Stile, not Old Stile, as he ſaid yeſterday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what do you ſay?

sp.speaker: 11th Witneſs.
sp.p: Mr. Poole was ſick, and I can remember when his Nephew went to him into the Infirmary before he went away from the Colledge, and he gave him good Counſel, as he ſaid, and I remember that Mr. Brett was ſick at Watton, and did come home again on Horſeback, and I believe he did not ſtir out; and Mr. Poole was at St. Omers, I am ſure I ſaw him once in two or three days all April and May. He went by the name of Killingbeck.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But he does not poſitively ſay he ſaw Sir Robert Brett every day there, he ſays he believes he did.

sp.speaker: 11th Witneſs.
sp.p: He came into the School and gave the Boys Queſtions to diſpute of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Call the reſt of your Witneſſes.

div.stage: Then another Witneſs was called and ſtood up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oats at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: I ſaw him almoſt every other day from the time he came till he went away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was the firſt time you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: The beginning of December.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee him in April there?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw him in April there at an Action.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And did you ſee him in May there?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I can teſtifie I ſaw him the firſt day of May in the Garden.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long ſtaid he there?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: Till June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to take ſuch preciſe notice?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: By his very place I could not but take notice if he were miſſing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can you ſay you ſaw him in the Garden the firſt of May?

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: I'll tell your Lordſhip why, becauſe there was a great Feaſt, and he play'd at Nine-pins in the Garden, and I can tell what they play'd for.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you as to Mr Nevil, and Sir. Robert Brett's being at St Omers.

sp.speaker: 12th Witneſs.
sp.p: I did not take ſo much notice of Sir Robert Brett, as for Nevil, I think I ſaw him once in three days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: And there is nothing ſaid of him here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr Oats firſt at St Omers?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: I firſt ſaw him in the Month of December.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee him in April and May?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there all thoſe Months?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Was he there all the Month of June?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: He went away towards the latter end of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Yeſterday you ſaid the latter end of July. Call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. North.
sp.p: Come you, hear the Queſtion, Did you ſee Mr Oats at St Omers, in the Month of April?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was there all the Month of April.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there all the Month of May?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: And a good part of June?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: What do you ſay as to Mr. Poole?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: I ſaw Mr. Poole in the Infirmary the third day of May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: How came you to take notice of it, ſo well as to remember it that it was the third of May?

sp.speaker: 13th Witneſs.
sp.p: It was a Feſtival Day. And the Feaſt we kept was the Invention of the Holy Croſs. We had the Action the day before, and ſome that were in the Infirmary would have it Acted over again to them, and we did ſo. My Lord, within one or two days after, Mr. Hilſly went away, I diſcourſed with Mr. Oats about half an hour; he came out within a day or two after out of the Infirmary, and I ſaw him walking in the Gallery. And again, the 2d of May I ſaw him walking with one Mr. Burnaby, who arrived the day before, the firſt of May, and then I ſaw him the 3d, 4th, and 5th; in this Burnaby's company; I ſaw him again the 26th of May, with a Band about his head in order to Confirmation, for they always have a Linnen Cloth bound about their head at ſuch a time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call another.
sp.stage: (Who ſtood up, his name was Lydcot.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ſay?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: All that I can ſay is this, that between the ſaid Month of December, 1677. and June, 1678. which is the time in Queſtion, Mr. Oats was never out of the Colledge above one night, when he went to Watton in January; and this is certain, that from the time that I ſaw him firſt, till the time he went away for altogether, there were not two days that paſſed away wherein I did not ſee him, except in the Month of March, and when he was in the Infirmary the 24th of April, but then I heard that he was there—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: The man that keeps that part of the Houſe; and coming into my Office after my Recovery out of a Fit of Sickneſs a week before Chriſtmas or thereabouts, I ſaw Mr. Oats by this Circumſtance, The Servitors of the Houſe ſaid they were glad to ſee me, and Mr. Oats being in that Place at the Refectory that was aſſigned to him, I asked who he was, and they told me ſuch an one, but I had heard of his admiſſion a few days before. Likewiſe Mr. Oats was there when Mr. Hilſly came for England, which was about the 24th of April, by this Circumſtance, that he was preſent in the Refectory with ſome of the Scholars Mr. Richard Burnaby came to the Colledge about a week after Mr. Hilſly went away, and Mr. Oats was actually there then, and we did very much wonder that he became acquainted with him ſo quickly after his arrival. I ſay Mr. Oats was actually there when Mr. Killingbeck and Mr. Conqueſt came for England about the 3d of May, by this Circumſtance, that I had ſome diſcourſe with Mr. Oats, and ſome others of the Scholars, that Mr. Conqueſt would by no means get out of his Bed betimes that day he was to go away, being unwilling to leave the Colledge. He was there the 26th of May by this Circumſtance, that the Biſhop dined there that day, and Mr. Oats was there Confirmed that day. Mr. Oats was there alſo in June my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes he was there in June, he does not deny it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: And was he there all May?

sp.speaker: Lydcott.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was, and all April, except the time he was in the Infirmary, which was 3 or 4 days.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: What do you ſay as to Poole and Nevil?

sp.speaker: Lydcott.
sp.p: They were there all the whole time in queſtion, and they were never abſent any competent time to come to England, as he ſays.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: We muſt not allow that, you muſt tell us what time they were there, that we may know it.

sp.speaker: Lydcott.
sp.p: They were there in March, April, May, June and July.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But did you ſee him every day from the beginning Chriſtmas to the time he went away in June?

sp.speaker: Lydcott.
sp.p: Yes, except the time he was at Watton, and when he was in the Infirmary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: But was not Mr. Oats twice in the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He was I remember there on St. Thomas of Canterbury's Day, and I remember he was there in April.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: I did here you ſay ſomething of ſome body that was abſent five or ſix days, was it you?

sp.speaker: Lydcott.
sp.p: I was ſick in the Month of March, and I was in the Infirmary till about the 12 or 14 day.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: And did you ſee him there all that time?

sp.speaker: Lydcott.
sp.p: I excepted that time, but I heard his voice once in that time in the next Room to the Infirmary, where I was by this Circumſtance; He uſed to come to a Table by himſelf, and it was near the Door, and Nevil and Poole were there, as I ſaid before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: He ſpeaks much more to the purpoſe to day Mr. Langhorne than he did yeſterday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: And much louder.

sp.speaker: Langhorne.
sp.p: I hope your Lordſhip will take notice that he ſpeaks likewiſe of the Reſidence of Mr. Poole, Sir Robert Brett, and Mr. Nevil.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes I do. Call another Witneſs.

div.stage: (Who ſtood up, and being a Foreigner, his Evidence was likewiſe Interpreted.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays he ſaw Mr. Oats, he was there, and he remembers it, till about the 25 of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did he ſee him?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays it was either in the Houſe, or in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North.
sp.p: When was that, that he was in the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays, he was in the Infirmary towards the latter end of December or beginning of January.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him what he ſays about Nevil and Poole.

sp.speaker: Interpreter.
sp.p: He ſays they were there all June, and that Mr. Poole went away in the Month of July; and he further ſays, that he being a Waterman, he carried this ſame Williams and March in hiſ Boat the laſt Sunday in April.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt. North.
sp.p: Who is your next, Mr. Langhorn? let him ſtand up: (which he did) When did you ſee Mr. Oates at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: 16th Witneſs.
sp.p: In the month of April, 1678.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And in May too was he?

sp.speaker: 16th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was Mr. Poole there all that time?

sp.speaker: 16th Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, he was, and ſo was Mr. Nevil and Mr. Bret.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: Where is Nevil now?

sp.speaker: 16th Witneſs.
sp.p: I believe left him there.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What are theſe perſons?

sp.speaker: 16th Witneſs.
sp.p: The one is a Prefect, and I believe he is there ſtill. In the month of May I made Mr. Killingbeck a Sute of Clothes, and Mr. Oates came into the Shop, and asked me whoſe clothes they were? I ſaid Mr. Killingbecks: ſaid he, how can that be? they are black: ſaid I, they muſt be black, for he is in mourning.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Grove's Wife and his Maid.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What queſtion would you ask of her?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Mr. Oates hath ſworn, and given us ſeveral circumſtances of his coming over, and being here at that which he calls the Conſult, and that he lay at Mr. Groves three or four nights; I deſire ſhe may be asked that queſtion, whether he did ſo or no?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Oates, Mrs. Grove?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: No, I never ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: Were there any Lodgers lay at your houſe in April was twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord there were.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you uſe to have Lodgers that you do not know?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: My houſe was full of Lodgers at that time. I did not know them till they lay there.

sp.speaker: Sir Creſw. Levins.
sp.p: Why then, Mr. Oates might be there, and you not know him.

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: If he lay there, I muſt needs know him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Why might not a man lye with any of your Lodgers three or four nights, and you not know him?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: Who ſhould he lye withall my Lord?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I had a bed to my ſelf when I lay there.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Oates deſcribe the Chamber as well as you can.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It was a place taken out of another Room, where two men were taken out that were committed to priſon.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: Were there any perſons taken out of your houſe, and ſent to priſon?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, there were.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: In that very Room he lay out of which thoſe perſons were taken.

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: He did not.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Upon my Oath I did lye there 3 or 4 nights more or leſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: You were in a diſguiſe Sir at that time, were you not, and went by another name, and ſo the woman might not known you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You cannot make any great matter of this, ſhe had ſome Lodgers and ſhe knew them, but he went by a wrong name, and was in a diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Mrs. Grove ſays, ſhe knew all the Lodgers that then lay there, pray ask her if ſhe did not?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you remember who lodged in your houſe in April was a twelve month?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Name them.

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: Why, there was one pair of ſtairs, one Mr. Strange by Name, and one Mrs. Fitzherbert, and above there lay my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What, all the month of May and April?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And not in June?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: I am not demanded of June.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: She anſwers exactly to them two months, what ſay you to March?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: They were there in March.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who lay in the Room from whence the men were taken that were carried to priſon?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: There was one Maſter Crupper, and another young man that lay with him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why might not that be Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: He was one that was a Priſoner by Mr. Oates Order. And Mrs. Fitzherbert lay there.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What, in that Room whence the young men were taken out in April or May?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you to the other months, March, and June and July?

sp.speaker: Grove.
sp.p: I was not to be examined further than the two Months I ſpoke of before.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Look you, ſhe ſays, that for April and May two Gentlemen had the Lodging that Mr. Oates ſays he lay in; but for any other time ſhe was not to be examined: Well, have you any more witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Here is Mrs. Grove's Maid:

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Maid, Can you tell who lay in Grove's houſe in April and May was twelvemonth?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I can.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who were they?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: There was my Miſtreſſes Brother and Siſter lay there.

sp.speaker: Mr Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Do you know them all? what men lay there?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: None but Maſter Strange, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Miſtris Groves ſaid, that her houſe was full.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord, there was her Brother, Mr York and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But who is that Fitzherbert?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: She is a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who lay there in March? And who lay there in July?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Maſter Strange, and Miſtreſs Fitzherbert.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long did they lye there?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: In April, May, June, July and Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: She ſayes, they lay there in March, April, May, June, July and Auguſt, and her Miſtreſs ſaid, they were there but a quarter of a year, only ſhe ſaid ſhe was to be examined no further.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to prove a Copy of the Record in the Lords Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: That is not to be given in Evidence here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: You know how far ſuch a thing will be Evidence, manage your own Evidence well.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: It is an Extract out of the Journal of the Houſe of Lords.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What particular do you pitch upon?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: About thoſe perſons who, he ſays, came over with him from St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt. North.
sp.p: Do you think it reaſonable, that any man ſhould come to anſwer now all that ever he hath ſworn in his life? If you can ſhew any Record to contradict what he hath ſworn here, ſhew it. Do you think he can come prepared to juſtifie all he hath ſworn in any other place?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: He referred to that himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: No, he does not.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: But he hath ſaid over and over, that Sir John Warner came over with him, Sir Tho. Preſton, and Poole.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: What ſhould you urge that Book for? Can you make any other proof?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: I would have the perſons called that took the Narrative of Ireland's Tryal.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: If you have any more Witneſſes, call them.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Won't your Lordſhip allow me to prove by Witneſſes what he affirmed in relation to me at another Tryal?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: By no means, you muſt not meddle with that.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, why not? I will prove the words ſpoken by a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt. North.
sp.p: You muſt not, that is no Evidence againſt you, nor can it be an Evidence for you.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Then you take off the Defence that I have, and make it as if I had never any.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: That is not Evidence in a Civil Cauſe, and therefore muſt not be Evidence here.

div.stage: Then came in my Lord of Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: What do you come for, Sir? What is your Name?

sp.speaker: E. Caſtlemain.
sp.p: My Name is Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Are you my Lord of Caſtlemain?

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Does your Lordſhip come as a Witneſs for Mr. Langhorn? Mr. Langhorn, do you call my Lord of Caſtlemain?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I don't know what he comes for, whether he comes as a Witneſs for me or not, perhaps he may.

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain.
sp.p: My Lord, I come to wait upon your Lordſhip and the Court to give you an account, that ſome of the Witneſſes that were ſummoned here for the Priſoners are ſo beaten and abuſed without, that they dare not come to give their Evidence, for fear of being killed.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: That is a thing that is not to be ſuffered, let us but ſee any perſon that dares but offer to meddle with them, and I'le aſſure you we will take care to ſee them puniſhed according as they do deſerve.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just. North.
sp.p: 'Tis a very unjuſtifiable thing, a thing that we will very ſeverely puniſh, if they be hindred of free ingreſs and regreſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a very horrid thing that they ſhould be ſo abuſed, they ought to have their liberty of coming and giving their Evidence here without any moleſtation.

sp.speaker: E. of Caſtlemain.
sp.p: I can aſſure your Lordſhip, that one of them was ſo beaten and bruiſed, that we can't tell but it may coſt him his life.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p:
Nay, we muſt look to ſuch a thing as that; for it is by no means to be allowed of. If your Lordſhip will but tell us who they
are, let us but know them, and we will take care for the puniſhment of them; for we will ſhew our ſelves juſt and fair, and give them all the fair play that can be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Mr. Langhorn, have you any more Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Mr Langhorn.
sp.p: Call the woman that kept the white-horſe-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: To what purpoſe do you call this Woman?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: I deſire, my Lord, to ask one Queſton of Mr Oates, touching the Conſult at the White-horſe-Tavern in the Strand; How many perſons met there?

sp.speaker: Dr Oates.
sp.p: Before that Queſtion be asked, I pray your Lordſhip would ask her, When ſhe came to the White-horſe-Tavern to keep it?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: I don't keep it now.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When did you keep it?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: I kept it in June, and I left it the beginning of July.

sp.speaker: Dr Oates.
sp.p: She does not come to the time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you keep it all the Year before that?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: I kept it ſeven years before, till July laſt.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: I would know of him, How many might be there at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What number of perſons do you ſay met at that Conſult?

sp.speaker: Dr Oates.
sp.p: That Queſtion, if it pleaſe your Lordſhip hath ho reference to this Tryal, neither is it at all material, but becauſe I have given the Priſoners ſo much freedom, they impoſe upon me with Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: 'Tis a Queſtion they can't expect a preciſe Anſwer to from you; But yet I would have you give them as ſatisfactory an Anſwer as you can, what number there might be there at a time.

sp.speaker: Dr Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I think there might be at the White-horſe-Tavern at a time about eighteen or twenty.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Were they in one Room, or in ſeveral Rooms?

sp.speaker: Dr Oates.
sp.p: They were in two or three Rooms.

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Is this Mr Oates, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, that he is.

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: I never ſaw him in my houſe in my life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there no body never in your Tavern but who you knew? What! can you tell all the people that were ever in your Tavern?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: The moſt of my Company were people that I knew.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What is your Company?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: Thoſe that frequented my houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Can you ſay who was in your houſe April 24, 1678?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I will not undertake that, but I will give you as true an account as I can.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: I'll tell you why I ask this Queſtion, Mr Oates did ſay in his Depoſitions before the Lords, there met fifty.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: At ſeveral times in the Day.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: But this muſt all be in the morning.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why ſo? ſuppoſe there met of that Company twenty in the morning, and then ſome went away, and others came in their Room, and ſo they did for divers times in the day, is not this properly ſaid of me, that there might be about fifty at that Conſult.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: He ſaith in Coleman's Tryal there met fifty upon the 24th of April, and afterwards they adjourned into leſſer Colloquies.

sp.speaker: Dr Oates.
sp.p: I ſay they met there the 24th. day, but the Conſult was not diſſolved till the 26th. day at night.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt. North.
sp.p: You muſt go only upon what is ſworn now. And we ask the Queſtion upon your Propoſal, How many were there at a time? and he ſays about eighteen or twenty at a time. Now if he proves there were eighteen at one time, twenty at another time, and ten at another, that makes about fifty.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Good woman, is your houſe a little houſe?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſmall inconſiderable houſe, there is not a Room in it that will hold above a dozen, I never remembred ſo great a company was in my houſe at one time but once in all my ſeven years, and that was a Jury of the Pariſh, and they could not be together, but were divided into three Rooms.

div.stage: Then there ſtood up a Stranger who was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, do you know the White Horſe Tavern in the Strand?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I do very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know the biggeſt Room in the Houſe?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, I do, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How many may dine there?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs.
sp.p: It may be twenty people, I have ſeen a dozen or ſixteen there often.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you know the Tavern a year ago?

sp.speaker: 1 Witneſs.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, this was a year ago.

div.stage: Then a ſecond Witneſs it stood up in the Court, and ſaid, that twenty five or thirty might dine in one Room that was backward, and another that was forward. And a third attested, that he was at a Wedding, and there did dine above twenty in one Room next the street.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: If ſhe make a Jury to be in three Rooms, that is but four in a Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Thoſe Juries are ſixteen generally or more.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I don't know this Tavern my ſelf; but I thought it very conſiderable, if they had not a Room that would hold ſuch a number as he ſpoke of, fifty.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But you ſee how unfortunately it happens, the matter had not been much, if it had been proved; but it's very unlucky that theſe perſons ſhould be here in Court by whom the other is contradicted; it had been better it were never medled with. That ſhe ſhould be ſo peremptory in what ſtanders by know to be falſe, makes this contradiction in one thing to give a ſuſpicion, that all your Witneſſes may be falſe in all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: Here is a Gentleman of good Quality that ſaith, there have been fifty in a Room.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope neither the Court nor the Jury will reflect upon me for this.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: No, it can't do that, but it reflects upon your Evidence, eſpecially this woman.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: I have been a Priſoner ſo long, and I know nothing but what Friends and Relations inform me.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: The thing was reaſonably offered, but it proves ſo unfortunate it will not hold. Have you any more Witneſſes to call?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I pray call them.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire I may examine them after the Kings Counſel have done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You may ſay what you will for your defence, but you muſt examine no new Witneſſes then, Mr. Langhorn.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: I muſt ask this Gentleman a Queſtion or two, if the Court think fit.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Propoſe them to the Court, what is it you would have?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, it is in relation to a matter that happened at Irerlands Tryal, I know not whether it be proper, but the Queſtion I would ask, is, whether Ireland were here in August or no?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He hath given you no occaſion to ask this Queſtion at this Tryal: And is there any reaſon that we ſhould examine him to ſuch a thing? Do you think it reaſonable, or according to Law, that Mr. Oates ſhould be examined in your Tryal concerning what he then ſaid of Irelands being here in August, or not being here, when 'tis no part of his accuſation that he brings againſt you? Can he be imagined to be prepared for ſuch a Juſtification, ſince he does not at all give any Evidence of it here?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Since he gave not any occaſion or uſe for ſuch a proof now at this time, 'tis not fit he ſhould be examined about it: Indeed yeſterday he gave it in Evidence, becauſe it concerned a circumſtance of time that related to the Priſoners then to be tryed.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: 'Tis true as my Lord ſayes, That it was yeſterday proper, becauſe he gave Evidence that Fenwick and Ireland were here in Anguſt together. Now that did ſome way concern him, but you have no concern at all in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: That brought it in at that time, but this is a foreign matter it cannot be here.

sp.speaker: Lord C. J.
sp.p: Have you any more Witneſſes, Maſter Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Oates hath affirmed, when I asked him touching his receiving a Reward, he ſaid, he had his Reward, for he had been out of purſe ſix or ſeven hundred pound, and it is my deſire to examine a couple of Witneſſes touching the probability of that; for he was ſo very poor before this happened, that it is impoſſible without a Purſe being made for him to lay out ſix or ſeven hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Look you, here is the thing, he gives you an Anſwer to which he was not in the leaſt bound, nor is it to be charged by you; he ſayes he is out 700l, but that is not any Evidence, nor is the Jury to take notice of it, nor is it to affect him. And would you have him give us an account how he came by that money?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I'le tell you how far it concerns me, the proving of his Indigency before this thing happened, will concern me thus far,—

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: If you ſhould prove this man in an indigent condition, what is that to the preſent purpoſe, it goes to no part of the Evidence.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: My Lord, I ask the Queſtion for this Reaſon, for certainly if he were ſo very indigent, it cannot be imagined in probability that any man would truſt him with ſuch a great ſumm, unleſs it were to give this Evidence.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: If you have any more Witneſſes call them, and make an end of them; if not, then you may obſerve what you will to the Court and Jury after the Kings Council hath done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: But all your Witneſſes you muſt call now.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Doth your Lordſhip debar me from uſing this Copy of the Record of the Houſe of Lords?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: To what purpoſe would you have it read?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: Becauſe Bedloe therein ſays, that he had no perſon more to charge either in the houſe or out of the houſe, than what he then charged.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: I was not one of thoſe perſons, then he knew nothing againſt me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis but a memorial taken by a Clerk, and do you think that his Omiſſion ſhall be concluſive to us?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: 'Tis the Journal of the Lords Houſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: But can you think that can be uſed as Evidence here? If you had an Affidavit ſigned by the party, and had witneſſes to prove that he did make ſuch an Oath, you ſay ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mr Juſt. Pember.
sp.p: You can't read that againſt his Teſtimony, you underſtand that being a Lawyer. If you have any Witneſſes call them, but you pick out collateral matters, and ſpend our time to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Really if it were a thing conducing to the point, I would very much ſtretch; but it being ſuch a kind of thing as this is, he ſays he had nothing to ſay againſt any body elſe, and I was not named then: what is this to the Fact you are charged with?

sp.speaker: Mr J. Pemb.
sp.p: Why, it may be he did not remember it then, will you conclude him that he ſhould never remember it, or ſpeak of it?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſee that now at theſe Tryals, he ſays ſometimes, this is all I can remember at preſent, but by and by he recollects himſelf; would you hinder him from ſaying then what he remembers?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Beſides, upon an Affidavit or an Anſwer in Chancery we never allow it, unleſs we have the party to prove that he took the Oath.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: I deſire to know of Mr. Oates, whether he did diſtribute any of theſe Commiſſions, and to whom? for he hath ſaid I did.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: That which I ſay is this, thoſe Commiſſions that I named they were diſtributed, but the perſons I do not know; I know the Commiſſions were for thoſe five perſons, and in July or Auguſt he did ſay he had diſtributed them, but he ſaid not to whom, only one indeed he ſent by his Son to the eldeſt Son of my Lord Arundel of Warder to be Commiſſary General, and he came back, and ſaid, it was delivered.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: You do not ſpeak of any other?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I do not recollect that I know of any other.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: I ask for this reaſon, becauſe, in the Lords houſe he hath charged me, that I ſent my Lord Arundel's Commiſſion, and that I ſent it by my Son, and that he ſaw a Letter in my Chamber of the receipt of it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, there is ſome part of the Evidence that does reflect upon the Lords, which I charge not upon Mr. Langhorn, becauſe I would not diſcover my Evidence againſt the Lords. He goes now to expatiate upon the Informations, but I hope the Court wilt excuſe me, becauſe I reſerve it for another Tryal.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: I deſire Mr. Lydcot may be asked whether he did not hear Maſter Oates at a former Tryal, ſay, (for ſo I find it in the Narrative,) (it was at Coleman's Tryal) that he came to me the next day after the Conſult, and communicated it to me, and that he never ſaw me afterwards.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know any Teſtimony Maſter Oates gave concerning Maſter Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: You are not the perſon that took the Tryal, are you?

sp.speaker: Lydcot.
sp.p: I know nothing of the buſineſs at all, I was at the Tryal, but I cannot particularly ſpeak what was ſaid there.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: The Perſons that took the Tryal were ſummoned to be here. Call Mrs. Sylliard. (But ſhe appeared not) Call Mr. Blayney.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Blayney, what would you ask him?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: I would know of him what Mr. Oates hath teſtified concerning me?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know what Mr. Oats ſaid concerning Mr. Langhorn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: When, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Nay, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Langh.
sp.p: At Coleman's Tryal, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Blayney.
sp.p: My Lord, I was preſent at Coleman's Tryal, and I remember Mr. Oates did ſay ſomething about Mr. Langhorn, but I have not my Book here, I can't tell what it was.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Here is the Book, Sir, here is the Narrative.

sp.speaker: Mr Blayney.
sp.p: That was not printed by my Copy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: Who were they that did take it?

sp.speaker: Mr Blayney.
sp.p: Of my own knowledge I don't know whoſe Copy it was, but by hear ſay.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: It was taken as well as it could be taken, but you muſt not urge that which is but an Hiſtorical Narrative againſt him.

sp.speaker: Mr Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Mr. Langhorn, do you think to convict a Man by an Hiſtory? To ſay that a Man is forſworn becauſe he does not ſwear as that Hiſtory ſays he did ſwear?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: We will do you all the right, and give you all the fair play we can; but we are of opinion that it ſignifies nothing, that you can make no uſe of it.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: If I can have no light, how can I imagine what they will charge me with?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt▪
sp.p: Have you in any other Caſe obſerved it? If a man be indicted of Felony or Treaſon, any Capital Crime, he is clapt up, and is not permitted to have a Copy of the Indictment, nor he cannot by Law.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: They know ſomething of what they are accuſed for, they are confronted before a Juſtice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Why, I'll ſuppoſe you had been examined, do you think your Examination would have been Evidence for you here?

div.stage: Then one Elizabeth Sylliard was called, but affirming, That She durſt not ſpeak, unleſs the Court would promiſe her protection againſt the Rabble, becauſe ſome of the Witneſſes had been abuſed; which the Court not being able to do otherwiſe than by promiſing to puniſh thoſe that offered to meddle with her if She brought them before them, She was, by Mr. Langhorn's Conſent, ſet aſide, and not examined.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: She comes in relation to a point that happened at Reading's Tryal, where Mr. Bedloe did depoſe, That he did not ſay all he could have ſaid againſt Mr. Whitebread, and Mr. Fenwick, but that he knew more againſt them than he gave in Evidence at their firſt Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: What is that to you?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: That I take to be a kind of Perjury in him; for they are ſworn, To ſpeak the Truth, the whole Truth, and nothing but the Truth.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: Is this material in your Caſe what he ſaid about Whitebread and Fenwick?

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: It makes it material to make him uncreditable.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Whitebread made that objection, but he was anſwered; for he was told, That he could not tell all that he knew at that time, becauſe he was in treaty with Mr. Reading about the leſſening his Evidence againſt them, and the Lords in the Tower, and the Lords were to judge what meaſure they ſhould have from him by his kindneſs to Whitebread and Fenwick. If you have no more, the Kings Counſel will go on.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p:
My Lord and Gentlemen of the Jury, you have heard the Evidence that Mr. Langhorn hath given for the making of his defence, which hath been principally to reflect upon Mr. Oates; and he firſt calls Mr Hilſly to prove, that whereas Mr. Oats did ſwear he came over with him, he affirms he did not; but it falls out, that Mr. Oats hath counterproved him by ſuch a circumſtance as does contradict him in what he ſays; for ſpeaking of the loſs of his money, Hilſly ſaid, ſome body elſe had told him
of it; but producing his Witneſs for that, he only affirms, that Mr. Oats in his company was told, that Mr. Hilſly had loſt his money, but not how nor where; but Mr. Oats gives you a particular circumſtance, that he was cheated by a perſon he lent his money to, and that left him to pay the Reckoning, which Mr. Hilſley does confeſs was true, and which he could not hear from the others, for the others did never know it. Gentlemen, they have brought you a great many other Witneſſes to prove, that Mr. Oates was not in England on the 24th of April, the time he ſays he was, and they all agree as to that time, tho' as to other times they are not ſo exact; but we ſhall give you as plain and as full an Evidence that he was here at that time, as that you are there now, and ſhall very fully ſatisfie you in it. For that of Sir John Warner, and Sir Thomas Preſton they are matters that were tranſacted beyond Sea, to be ſure they did not come over by thoſe Names, no more did Mr. Oats himſelf; therefore it would be hard to find out theſe Perſons, or to give you ſo particular an account of them that were thus in Diſguiſes, and had changed their Names; but truly if that were a matter done in England, it were far more eaſie for us to confront their Teſtimony in that; for matters that are done here lye more ready for our proof, than thoſe that are done beyond Sea; for the laſt woman that he called, which was the woman about the White Horſe Tavern, her Evidence would have gone as punctually for truth, if it had been a matter done in Flanders, as any thing could be in the world; but it happening to be near home, it hath the ill fortune to meet with a very ſudden Anſwer, which is a manifeſt proof how they ſtretch to help themſelves, and in my opinion this contradiction overthrows all their Evidence. Gentlemen, we will call out Witneſſes, and prove it as plainly as any thing can be in the world, that Mr. Oats was here at that time. Firſt ſwear Will. Walker (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Oats?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have known him ſeven or eight years.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When did you ſee him in England laſt year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I ſaw him the latter end of March 1678. or towards the middle of April following, I ſaw him then in a diſguiſe, inſomuch as that I knowing what he was, and what he had been, I could not a great while recollect the face of the man, and it was a great trouble to me, that having known him ſo many years, I ſhould not then know him. I went home, but could not recollect my ſelf that night; but before I roſe again the next morning, I did recollect my ſelf that it was Titus Oats, and I preſently turned my ſelf out of my bed, and went to a Gentlewoman whoſe name I did not then well know, to inquire of her about it. After the Salutation, ſaid I, How does Mr. Oats? ſaid ſhe, knocking her hand upon the Counter, He is an undone man: Why, what is the matter, ſaid I? He is turned, ſaid ſhe, to the Church of Rome: Do you know where he is, ſaid I? No, ſaid ſhe, but he is lurking up and down the Town, and only dares appear in the evenings. Well then, ſaid I, I ſaw him later than you did; for I ſaw him between St. Martins-lane and Leiceſter houſe yeſterday, but he was in a diſguiſe: and I told her what habit he was in.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What time was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: It was about ten of the clock in the morning.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But what time of the year was it?

sp.speaker: Mr Walker.
sp.p: It was the latter end of March, or the middle of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: It was before the end of April?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Ay, ay, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
And that contradicts all your Witneſſes; for they ſay, that he
was there all March and all April and all May, nay from December to June.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: He hath ſaid the latter end of March, or the middle of April, I would have him be as certain as he can.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He cannot be certain; for thoſe things in point of time, you know and all mankind muſt agree, that a thing done a year ago that was of no greater importance at that time, cannot ſo eaſily be remembred, or that he ſhould take ſuch ſpecial notice of the critical day. What man in the world does remember or take notice ſo as to charge himſelf in what week or what month ſuch an accidental thing as this happened? But to ſatisfie Mr. Langhorn I ask you, Can you ſpeak any more particularly than you have done?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Becauſe I would not be miſtaken or do any one any wrong, I do rather take an uncertain time than a certain, but I do think it was in the month of April and towards the middle of the month, that is all I can ſay.

sp.speaker: Langhorn.
sp.p: But how is he ſure, ſince he is ſo uncertain in his memory, that this was 1678, and not 1677?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Becauſe, my Lord, it was but a little more than a year ſince, and I am able to judge of the year as well as another.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you remember what you went about?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I was wont about that time of year to receive money of my Lord Thomas Howard, and upon that Errand I came to Town then.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But are you ſure it was Mr. Oats that you ſaw?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord; for according to my apprehenſion I did know the face when I firſt ſaw it, but I could not recollect who it was till I had refreſhed my memory, and the next morning I did ſo, and then concluded it was he.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
sp.p: I was brought here for a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Did you diſcover this to Mr. Oats, or did Mr. Oats firſt come to you, to put you in mind of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Walker.
